articles.headline: Palestinian Reports Unity Deal With Hamas
articles.snippet: A tentative agreement between the Fatah faction and Hamas is an attempt to regain Western aid donations.
articles.abstract: A tentative agreement between the Fatah faction and Hamas is an attempt to regain Western aid donations.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Greg Myre

articles.headline: Freescale Considers Rival Bids
articles.snippet: Two private equity groups are dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor for more than $16 billion, people involved said.
articles.abstract: Two private equity groups are dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor for more than $16 billion, people involved said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two private equity groups are now dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker that was spun off from Motorola two years ago, for more than $16 billion, people involved in the negotiations said.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Barnaby J. Feder

articles.headline: A Tortoise Savors the Lead
articles.snippet: CBS is heading into the fall season as the most watched network in prime time, but in the treacherous world of broadcast TV, there is little certainty.
articles.abstract: CBS is heading into the fall season as the most watched network in prime time, but in the treacherous world of broadcast TV, there is little certainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, it was a week to savor.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Bill Carter

articles.headline: House Panel and U.S. Attorney Join H.P. Inquiry
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard came under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard came under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 — As its directors continued to confer on the future of its chairwoman, Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks in the board.

articles.headline: Chevron Could Avoid Huge Royalties on New Field
articles.snippet: A group of companies led by Chevron could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government.
articles.abstract: A group of companies led by Chevron could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 — A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which said last week that they had discovered a huge new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for the oil.

articles.headline: Dismissal Recommended for Bristol Chief
articles.snippet: Peter R. Dolan’s troubled five-year tenure as chief executive of the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb could soon come to an end.
articles.abstract: Peter R. Dolan’s troubled five-year tenure as chief executive of the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb could soon come to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made.

articles.headline: New Kid on the Rack
articles.snippet: The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies.
articles.abstract: The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHORTLY before 8 a.m. on a recent Tuesday morning, Christopher LaPolice was on the fifth floor of Saks Fifth Avenue, two hours before the store was to open. In a ritual that unfolds at the store each morning, the displays were cluttered with rolling racks and unopened cardboard boxes, and four young men were sorting through and stocking the latest Marc by Marc Jacobs dresses and cotton-candy-colored fake fur bomber jackets from Juicy Couture.

articles.headline: Grim Outlook Seen in West Iraq Without More Troops and Aid
articles.snippet: Anbar Province will continue to deteriorate without reinforcements, according to the report.
articles.abstract: Anbar Province will continue to deteriorate without reinforcements, according to the report.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 — The political and security situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate unless the region receives a major infusion of aid and a division is sent to reinforce the American troops operating there, according to the senior Marine intelligence officer in Iraq.

articles.headline: Grim Outlook Seen in West Iraq Without More Troops and Aid
articles.snippet: The political and security situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate unless the region receives a major infusion of aid and a division is sent to reinforce the American troops operating there, according to the senior Marin...
articles.abstract: The political and security situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate unless the region receives a major infusion of aid and a division is sent to reinforce the American troops operating there, according to the senior Marine intelligence officer in Iraq.     The assessment, prepared last month by Col. Peter Devlin at the Marine headquarters in Anbar Province, has been sent to senior military officials in Iraq and at the Pentagon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - The political and security situation in western Iraq is grim and will continue to deteriorate unless the region receives a major infusion of aid and a division is sent to reinforce the American troops operating there, according to the senior Marine intelligence officer in Iraq.

articles.headline: Dismissal Recommended for Bristol Chief
articles.snippet: A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the re...
articles.abstract: A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made.      If the board takes the action at a meeting today, it would end a troubled five-year tenure for the executive, Peter R. Dolan.
articles.lead_paragraph: A court-appointed overseer has recommended that the embattled head of Bristol-Myers Squibb be fired for his recent handling of a patent dispute that led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made.

articles.headline: New Kid on the Rack
articles.snippet: Article on Christopher LaPolice and Rea Laccone, business partners whose hot contemporary apparel label Vince is sold at upscale retailers; two comment on working for larger labels and decision to strike out on their own; photos (special section, ...
articles.abstract: Article on Christopher LaPolice and Rea Laccone, business partners whose hot contemporary apparel label Vince is sold at upscale retailers; two comment on working for larger labels and decision to strike out on their own; photos (special section, Small Business) (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: SHORTLY before 8 a.m. on a recent Tuesday morning, Christopher LaPolice was on the fifth floor of Saks Fifth Avenue, two hours before the store was to open. In a ritual that unfolds at the store each morning, the displays were cluttered with rolling racks and unopened cardboard boxes, and four young men were sorting through and stocking the latest Marc by Marc Jacobs dresses and cotton-candy-colored fake fur bomber jackets from Juicy Couture.

articles.headline: Chevron Could Avoid Huge Royalties on New Field
articles.snippet: A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which said last week that they had discovered a huge new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for the oil.     The potential bonus ...
articles.abstract: A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which said last week that they had discovered a huge new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for the oil.     The potential bonus to Chevron and its partners stems from a mistake the Interior Department made in signing offshore leases in the late 1990's for drilling in federal waters. The magnitude of the oil discovery -- estimated in a range of 3 billion to 15 billion barrels -- is likely to intensify a battle in Congress over incentives for drilling in publicly owned waters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 - A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which said last week that they had discovered a huge new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for the oil.

articles.headline: Harvard Ends Early Admission
articles.snippet: Harvard University, breaking with a major trend in college admissions, says it will eliminate its early admissions program next year, with university officials arguing that such programs put low-income and minority applicants at a distinct disadva...
articles.abstract: Harvard University, breaking with a major trend in college admissions, says it will eliminate its early admissions program next year, with university officials arguing that such programs put low-income and minority applicants at a distinct disadvantage in the competition to get into selective universities.     Harvard will be the first of the nation's prestigious universities to do away completely with early admissions, in which high school seniors try to bolster their chances at competitive schools by applying in the fall and learning whether they have been admitted in December, months before other students.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harvard University, breaking with a major trend in college admissions, says it will eliminate its early admissions program next year, with university officials arguing that such programs put low-income and minority applicants at a distinct disadvantage in the competition to get into selective universities.
articles.byline: By Alan Finder and Karen W. Arenson

articles.headline: House Panel and U.S. Attorney Join H.P. Inquiry
articles.snippet: As its directors continued to confer on the future of its chairwoman, Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks in the board.     The Un...
articles.abstract: As its directors continued to confer on the future of its chairwoman, Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks in the board.     The United States attorney's office in San Francisco said it was looking into the methods used by the investigators, which included the questionable if not illegal tactic of ''pretexting'' -- posing as directors and journalists to get their phone records.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 - As its directors continued to confer on the future of its chairwoman, Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny Monday over the use of private investigators to trace the source of news leaks in the board.

articles.headline: Palestinian Reports Unity Deal With Hamas
articles.snippet: The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Monday that he had reached a tentative agreement with Hamas to form a national unity government in an attempt to end the Palestinians' international isolation and the cutoff in Western assis...
articles.abstract: The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Monday that he had reached a tentative agreement with Hamas to form a national unity government in an attempt to end the Palestinians' international isolation and the cutoff in Western assistance to their government.     In a speech on Palestinian television, Mr. Abbas said it would take several days to finish the deal, and provided no details of how his Fatah faction and the militant group Hamas, which leads the government, had resolved their considerable differences.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Greg Myre

articles.headline: President Bush Sees 'Struggle for Civilization'
articles.snippet: President Bush used the solemn day to assert that the United States was engaged in ''a struggle for civilization'' that would be determined in part by the course of the war in Iraq.      ''The safety of America depends on the outcome of the battle...
articles.abstract: President Bush used the solemn day to assert that the United States was engaged in ''a struggle for civilization'' that would be determined in part by the course of the war in Iraq.      ''The safety of America depends on the outcome of the battle in the streets of Baghdad,'' Mr. Bush said.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Bush used the solemn day to assert that the United States was engaged in "a struggle for civilization" that would be determined in part by the course of the war in Iraq.

articles.headline: Freescale Considers Rival Bids
articles.snippet: Two private equity groups are now dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker that was spun off from Motorola two years ago, for more than $16 billion, people involved in the negotiations said.      A deal would be the larges...
articles.abstract: Two private equity groups are now dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker that was spun off from Motorola two years ago, for more than $16 billion, people involved in the negotiations said.      A deal would be the largest leveraged buyout ever in the technology sector, surpassing the $11.3 billion sale of SunGard Data Systems last year. And it would be a vivid demonstration of both the widening ambitions of private equity and the changing fortunes of the semiconductor business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two private equity groups are now dueling to take over Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker that was spun off from Motorola two years ago, for more than $16 billion, people involved in the negotiations said.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Barnaby J. Feder

articles.headline: A Tortoise Savors the Lead
articles.snippet: For Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, it was a week to savor.     His decision to make Katie Couric the anchor of the ''CBS Evening News'' looked like a wildly successful bet, so far at least. On the entertainment side, C...
articles.abstract: For Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, it was a week to savor.     His decision to make Katie Couric the anchor of the ''CBS Evening News'' looked like a wildly successful bet, so far at least. On the entertainment side, CBS was set to go into the fall season as the most watched network in prime time.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Leslie Moonves, the chief executive of the CBS Corporation, it was a week to savor.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Bill Carter
